document.docAuthor: Chemyreva, Vasilisa G. & Perkovsky, Evgeny E. & Vasilenko, Dmitry V.
document.docTitle: First record of the parasitoid family Ismaridae (Hymenoptera, Diaprioidea) from Eocene Baltic and Rovno ambers with the description of a new genus and two new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First record of the parasitoid family Ismaridae (Hymenoptera, Diaprioidea) from Eocene Baltic and Rovno ambers with the description of a new genus and two new species

emphasis.docTitle: First record of the parasitoid family Ismaridae ( Hymenoptera, Diaprioidea ) from Eocene Baltic and Rovno ambers with the description of a new genus and two new species

subSection.paragraph: VASILISA G. CHEMYREVA 1,* , EVGENY E. PERKOVSKY 2 & DMITRY V. VASILENKO 3,4

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, 1 Universitetskaya Emb., St Petersburg 199034, Russia
Natural History Museum of Denmark , Universitetsparken 15, Copenhagen, 2100, Denmark
Cherepovets State University, Lunacharsky Prospect 5, Cherepovets, Vologda Region , 162600, Russia
Paleontological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Profsoyuznaya 123, Moscow , 117647, Russia

subSection.paragraph:
A new genus,
Lubomirus
gen. nov.
, of the family Ismaridae ( Hymenoptera, Diaprioidea ) from the late Eocene Baltic and Rovno ambers is described and illustrated. The new genus is the second known genus of the family Ismaridae . The two new species,
Lubomirus masneri
sp. nov.
from Rovno amber and
Lubomirus victori
sp. nov.
from Baltic amber, are described. The diagnosis of the Ismaridae family and the single extant genus of the familyâ
Ismarus Haliday
âare clarified. The systematic position of
Cretapria Fujiyama, 1994
is discussed.

Key words :
Ismaridae
, fossils , Cenozoic , Paleogene , European ambers , new genus

The monogeneric family Ismaridae includes 56 recent species from the genus
Ismarus Haliday, 1835
that are distributed everywhere ( Johnson, 1992 ; Masner, 1976 ; Kolyada & Chemyreva, 2016 ;
Kim et al. , 2018a
, b;
Yan et al. , 2023
). Species of
Ismarus
are hyperparasitoids of leafhoppers ( Hemiptera , Cicadellidae ) via Dryinidae Haliday, 1833 ( Hymenoptera , Chrysidoidea ). Dryinids from the genera
Anteon Jurine, 1807
and
Lonchodryinus Kieffer, 1905
( Dryinidae , Anteoninae ), as well as
Aphelopus Dalman, 1823
( Dryinidae , Apheloninae), are reported as the hosts of the five Palaearctic species of
Ismarus
( Chambers 1955 , 1981 ; Nixon 1957 ; Masner 1976 ; Jervis 1979 ; Olmi 2000 ;
Kim et al. , 2018a
). The two species of the genus
Lonchodryinus
were described from Eocene amber, as well as 22 species of other dryinid wasps (
Olmi et al. , 2021b
). However, there are no records documenting the discovery of
Ismarus
or other members of the Ismaridae family in Eocene fossils. The only fossil Ismaridae is the monotypic genus
Cretapria Fujiyama, 1994
( Fujiyama, 1994 ) described from Aptian Choshi amber (
Perkovsky et al. , 2020b
). Unfortunately, the original description and illustration of the genus are insufficient for an accurate taxonomic interpretation, and the real taxonomic position of the fossil species
C. tsukadai Fujiyama
remains doubtful.

The type material of the new species is deposited in the Schmalhausen Institute of Zoology of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine , Kiev ( SIZK ), the Natural History Museum of Denmark ( NHMD ) and A.A. Borissiak Paleontological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow ( PIN ). The Rovno amber specimen was collected most probably in Klesov (see data for old material labeled UA in Perkovsky, 2017 ). Data on the Klesov biota is summarized in
Mitov et al. (2021)
. The fragments containing the wasps were cut from the original pieces and then polished on all sides as described by Sidorchuk (2013) and Sidorchuk & Vorontsov (2018) . Images of holotypes were taken with a Nikon E-800 compound microscope equipped with an Olympus OM-D E-M10-II digital camera. Images of paratype were taken using a Leica MZ APO and Leica Z16 APO stereomicroscope equipped with a Leica DFC 450 camera and processed with LAS Core software. Final images were stacked using Helicon Focus 7.6. The morphological terminology and abbreviations follow Naumann (1982) and the Hymenoptera Anatomy Ontology (
Yoder et al. , 2010
). The venation terminology and abbreviations used in this text follow Naumann (1982) and correspond with the terminology used by Brazidec & Vilhelmsen (2022) , with a few exceptions: stigmal vein = r-rs; radial vein is the part of Rs located distally from r-rs, while the poststigmal vein is the part of Rs located proximally from r-rs ( Fig. 5B ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Small to medium size wasps ( 1â4 mm ) with mesoscutum and metasomal tergites strongly arched in lateral view; apex of metasoma curved down; head strongly transverse; antennae inserted low on face, right above clypeus, antennal shelf not developed; scape about 2.5 times as long as wide; antenna of female 15-segmented and male 14-segmented; males with modified (sex-segment) A3 and A4, or only one of them, or both not modified; notauli reduced to anterior pits or completely developed; fore wing without stigma but with slightly thickened marginal vein; metatibia incrassate and covered with thick bristles; metasoma distinctly petiolate with tergum 2 the longest; ovipositor entirely retracted; males, and most females, with one-segmented exposed cerci on T8.

Remarks. Masner (1976 , 1993 ) provided a detailed diagnosis of the genus
Ismarus
and Ismaridae in general, mainly based on morphological features such as: (1) female antennae 15-segmented, male antennae 14-segmented, with sex-segment usually being on A4, rarely on A3 or A3 and A4; (2) antennae with scape about 2.5 times as long as wide and inserted low on face, right above clypeus, antennal shelf not developed; (3) notauli always wanting, reduced to anterior pits; (4) mesosoma relatively short and highly convex dorsally, metasoma distinctly petiolate with tergum 2 the longest; (5) fore tibiae with regular spur and 1 false spur; (6) metatibia incrassate; (7) one-segmented cerci on T8 relatively long and not inserted in depressions in both sexes; (8) ovipositor entirely retracted. After Masnerâs revision of the New World fauna of the genus, twenty-nine species of
Ismarus
were described (
Liu et al. , 2011
; Kolyada & Chemyreva, 2016 ;
Kim et al. , 2018a
, b;
Zhang et al. , 2021
;
Yan et al. , 2023
). However, all diagnostic features remain universal for all known
Ismarus species.
Kim et al. (2018a)
reasonably mentioned an additional character in the family and genus diagnosis: âbase of second tergite with median furrowâ. The two new species described below conform to all features of the
Ismarus
diagnosis, except for three: the presence of the median furrow at the base of T2, the presence of the false spur on the fore tibiae, and the absence of notauli. These peculiarities, along with other morphological specialties of the new species, justify their classification as a separate genus within the family Ismaridae .

Type species:
Lubomirus victori
sp. nov.
Baltic amber, late Eocene, Priabonian.
Etymology. The new genus is named in honor of Dr. Lubomir Masner, a brilliant entomologist and expert on Diaprioidea , Proctotrupoidea , and Platygastroidea.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Ismaridae , faces. Aâ
Ismarus apicalis Kolyada, B
â
I. halidayi FÃ¶rster, C
â
Lubomirus masneri
sp. nov.
Scale bar: A, Bâ0.2 mm; Câ0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: ( Figs 2 , 3 )

paragraph.materialsCitation: Holotype , â : SIZK UA-1675 , Rivne Oblast , Rovno amber, late Eocene, Priabonian.Amber fragment with holotype is a triangular prism, sized 6.0: 4.5: 7.5: 1.3 mm .

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Fore wing with costal, subcostal, basal, marginal, and stigmal veins sclerotized; radial, postmarginal, and poststigmal veins visible as traces ( Fig. 3A ); traces of radial and postmarginal veins forming closed radial cell, which is as long as marginal vein; trace of radial vein straight. Mesopleuron in lateral view with straight epicnemial carina developed throughout mesopleuron, from tegula to its ventral side ( Figs 2B, 2C , 3B ).
Description. Female ( holotype ). Body length 1.3 mm ; antennae about 0.74 times as long as body; wing 0.85 times as long as body.

Head. Head smooth and bare, about twice as wide as long, slightly wider than mesosoma; POL: not visible; LOL: 1; OOL: 2; ocelli large, LOL as long as diameter of lateral ocellus; eye large and bare, 2.5 times as high as malar distance; face and cheek smooth with few scattered setae; clypeus convex, transverse, 1.6 times as wide as high; epistomal sulcus distinct; tentorial pits present; mandibles elongate, narrowed to the apex, symmetrical, bidentate.

Antenna. Filiform, stout; A1 cylindrical, 2.8 times as long as wide, covered with reticulate sculpture and scattered, short setae; A3 slightly shorter than A4, both about 1.35 times as long as wide, A5âA14 about 1.1 times as long as wide, A15 2.1 times as long as wide; A3âA15 covered with recumbent pubescence.

Mesosoma. Pronotum coarsely rugose between epomia in dorsal view; pronotal shoulders angled; lateral side of pronotum sculptured along vertical branch of epomia and almost smooth posteriorly; mesoscutum smooth and convex; notauli complete, deep and slightly crenulate; humeral sulcus longer than tegula, not crenulate; scutellum convex, sculptured along posterior margin; anterior scutellar pit large and deep, crenulate at bottom, without median keel ( Fig. 2A ); metanotum narrow, coarsely rugose laterally; characters of metascutum invisible; propodeum in dorsal view invisible; mesopleuron with deep mesepimeral sulcus, epicnemial carina and sculpture along anterior margin; metapleuron and lateral side of propodeum coarsely rugose and with few short, scattered setae; mesopleuron in ventral view with acetabular carina behind fore-coxa and crenulate mesodiscrimen; fore tarsal claws with a row of strong setae ventrally ( Fig. 3C red arrow); mid and hind tarsal claws with few strong setae ventrally ( Fig. 3D ); fore and mid legs slender; hind tibiae gradually swollen with carina on inner side.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Lubomirus masneri
, holotype, female. Aâhead and mesosoma in dorsal view; Bâface and antennae in ventral view; Câhead and mesosoma in dorso-lateral view. Scale bar 0.3 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Metasoma. Petiole short, with elongate carinae and few scattered setae; sutures between tergites complete and deeply impressed; T2 strongly convex in lateral view, smooth, covered with few scattered setae; base of S2 sculptured, with several deep elongate grooves ( Fig. 3B ). Other metasomal characters not visible.
Male. Unknown.
Etymology. The new species is named in honor of Dr. Lubomir Masner.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Lubomirus masneri
, holotype, female. Aâwhole insect, ventro-lateral view; Bâbody, ventro-lateral view; Câ fore tarsus; Dâhind legs. Scale bar (mm): Aâ0.5; Bâ0.2; C, Dâ0.1.

paragraph.materialsCitation: Holotype , â : PIN , 964/1341, Yantarnyj , Kaliningrad Oblast , Russia , Baltic amber, late Eocene, Priabonian. Amber fragment with holotype is right parallelepiped, sized 1.8: 1.8: 0.7 mm .

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype : â , NHMD 608356 , from the same locality as the holotype
.
Description. Female ( holotype ). Body length 1.1 mm ; antennae about 0.6 times as long as body; wing 0.7 times as long as body.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4.
Lubomirus victori ,
holotype, female. Aâwhole insect in lateral view; B, Eâbody, lateral views; Câfore wing and metasoma, dorsal view; Dâbody, dorsal view. Scale bar: Aâ0.5 mm; BâEâ0.3 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Head. Head smooth and bare, in dorsal view 1.9 times as wide as long, slightly wider than mesosoma; POL: 16; LOL: 9; OOL: 12; ocelli large, LOL as long as diameter of lateral ocellus; eye large and bare, 3.1 times as high as malar distance; face and cheek smooth with a few short setae; clypeus convex, transverse, 2.4 times as wide as high; epistomal sulcus distinct; tentorial pits tiny ( Fig. 5C blue arrow); mandibles elongate, narrowed to the apex, symmetrical, bidentate.

Antenna. Filiform, stout; A1 cylindrical, 2.6 times as long as wide, covered with coriaceous sculpture and scattered, short setae; A3 slightly shorter than A4, A6âA8 as long as wide, A9âA14 1.12 times as long as wide, A15 2.2 times as long as wide; A3âA15 covered with short pubescence and each with several appressed thickened sensillae ( Fig. 4B ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Lubomirus victori ,
holotype, female. Aâfore tarsus, Bâfore wing; Câface; Dâbody, ventral view. Vein name: m âmarginal, pm âpostmarginal, ps âpoststigmal, r âradial, s âstigmal. Scale bar 0.3 mm.

FIGURE 6.
Lubomirus victori ,
paratype, male. Aâlateral view; Bâdorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Metasoma. Petiole transverse, 1.6 times as wide as long, rugulose; sutures between tergites complete and deeply impressed; T2 convex in lateral view, entirely smooth with few scattered setae; T3âT6 short, with a row of setigerous punctures, T7 smooth, T8 with weakly prominent cerci. Base of S2 invisible, posterior part of S2 and S3âS6 smooth and almost bare, S3âS5 short, S6 subtrangular.

Male. Body length 1.1 mm , antennae 0.6 as long as body. Similar to female, but antennae more slender and covered with long setae, A3 and A4 not modified, A3 slightly shorter than A2 and A4 ( Fig. 6A ), A4âA13 about 2.5 times as long as wide ( Fig. 6B ); fore tarsal claws without setae ventrally; T8 with exposed cerci.
Etymology. The new species is named in honor of Victor Kolyada, enthusiastic entomologist and expert on Diaprioidea and Proctotrupoidea .

subSection.paragraph:
The new genus described here is very close to the single known extant genus of the family Ismaridae â
Ismarus
. Nevertheless, the species of
Ismarus
demonstrate amazing stability of some morphological characters: the strongly transverse head with widely separated mandibles, very short malar distance and strongly transverse clypeus; the absence of notauli and the presence of the deep furrows at the base of the syntergite. Both described, extinct species do not agree with these peculiarities of
Ismarus
morphology, but are almost fully concordant to the family characteristics discussed by Masner (1976) .

The genus
Cretapria
, mentioned as Ismaridae , [subfamily Ismarinae ( Diapriidae ) at the time of publication of the original description] with a single species
C. tsukadai Fujiyama, 1994
, was described from Choshi amber ( Japan ). Unfortunately, the holotype of this species was lost (Dr. Yasunari Shigeta pers. comm., 2019). Fujiyama (1994) suggested that the âthin Y-shaped vein seen at the basal part of the fore wing occasionally appears in the living species of Diapriidae and related families,â and placed the new species in the family Diapriidae . However, the new species do not have the antennal shelfâthe synapomorphy of all Diapriidae family members. Ismaridae is the closest relative to the Diapriidae group of wasps with similar venation and without an antennal shelf. âFrom only this point of view,
Cretapria
should be dropped into the subfamily Ismarinae [currently it is a separate family Ismaridae (Sharkey et. al., 2011)], but other features of
Cretapria
do not always correspond with those of Ismarinae â ( Fujiyama, 1994 ). The drawings and photo of
C. tsukadai
published by Fujiyama (1994) really do not demonstrate significant similarity of this wasp to the Ismaridae family members (as well as Diapriidae family members) and do not agree with the family diagnosis suggested above including the characteristics of the fore wing venation. Unfortunately, the low quality of the photos and drawings makes the interpretation of the species and genus doubtful: the available morphological data are ambiguous and insufficient to justify to which taxon
Cretapria
belongs. We consider that the taxon should be considered incertae sedis for the reasons discussed above.

We are very thankful to Dr. Toshiharu Mita (Entomological Laboratory, Faculty of Agriculture, Kyushu University) and Dr.Yasunari Shigeta (Department of Geology and Paleontology, National Science Museum, Tokyo) for their help with searching for the
Cretapria tsukadai Fujiyama
holotype . Thanks to Dr. Massimo Olmi (Tropical Entomology Research Center, Viterbo, Italy ) for consultations considering the Dryinidae and
Ismarus
biology, to Dr. Alexei Solodovnikov and Dr. Lars Vilhelmsen (both from NHMD ) for their generous help. We are very grateful to Dr. Dmitry Vorontsov (Koltzov Institute of Developmental Biology, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow) for his careful assistance in the preparation of the holotype photos and training to make 3D preparations of amber with inclusions. We offer our sincere gratitude to the reviewers for their valuable comments.

This study was performed as part of the State Research Project No 122031100272-3 for CVG; EEP was supported by Scholars at Risk Ukraine (SARU) program jointly funded by the Villum Foundation, the Carlsberg Foundation and the Novo Nordisk Foundation and by the grant âSupport and development of the amber collection of the Statens Naturhistoriske Museumâ from Dr. BÃ¸je Benzons StÃ¸ttefond. The contributions by the Augustinus Foundation (Grant 17-3904), the Knud HÃ¸jgaard Foundation (Grant 17-11-2728 ), and the Villum Foundation (Grant 00021155) enabled the acquisition of the Karin Nordmann Ernst amber collection to which the paratype specimen originally belonged.
